pullRequest.body:
We write down basic definitions for the discrete Fourier transform, and compute the Fourier transforms of primitive Dirichlet characters (a minor reformulation of a result from an earlier PR). 

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Thanks for the reviews guys! I'm going to review #13579 and then merge it here since it's clearly relevant.

### PR summary [16f43ac386](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13353/commits/16f43ac3864515f0ac4ba90cceb98cc0347e4534)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.MeasureTheory.MeasurableSpace.Instances | 517 | 590 | +73 (+14.12%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>8 files</summary> `Mathlib.Analysis.Fourier.AddCircle` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Sphere.Ptolemy` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Angle.Sphere` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Angle.Oriented.RightAngle` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Angle.Oriented.Rotation` `Mathlib.NumberTheory.ZetaValues` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Triangle` `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Angle.Oriented.Affine`</details>|1|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Complex.Circle`|2|
| `Mathlib.MeasureTheory.MeasurableSpace.Instances`|73|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Instances.ZMod`|623|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Fourier.ZMod`|1954|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ZMod.instMeasurableSingletonClass`
`+ ZMod.instMeasurableSpace`
`+ dft`
`+ dft_apply`
`+ dft_def`
`+ fourierTransform_eq_gaussSum_mulShift`
`+ fourierTransform_eq_inv_mul_gaussSum`
`+ instance : DiscreteTopology (ZMod N) := ⟨rfl⟩`
`+ instance : TopologicalSpace (ZMod N) := ⊥`
`+ stdAddChar`
`+ stdAddChar_apply`
`+ stdAddChar_coe`
`+ toAddCircle`
`+ toAddCircle_apply`
`+ toAddCircle_eq_zero`
`+ toAddCircle_inj`
`+ toAddCircle_injective`
`+ toAddCircle_intCast`
`+ toAddCircle_natCast`
`+ toCircle`
`+ toCircle_apply`
`+ toCircle_intCast`
`+ toCircle_natCast`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

I'm thinking of a middle ground. If applying some general lemma from the Fourier transform API "just works", then I don't see there's a pressing need to create a copy. So e.g. compatibility with scalar-multiplication works out of the box, but addition needs some side conditions:
```lean
example {N : ℕ} [NeZero N] (Φ : ZMod N → ℂ) (c : ℂ) : 𝓕 (c • Φ) = c • 𝓕 Φ := 
  VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_smul_const .. -- no need for a special DFT lemma

example {N : ℕ} [NeZero N] (Φ₁ Φ₂ : ZMod N → ℂ) : 𝓕 (Φ₁ + Φ₂) = 𝓕 Φ₁ + 𝓕 Φ₂ := by
  rw [Eq.comm] -- doh!
  apply VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_add 
  · continuity
  · continuity
  · measurability
  · measurability
```
(This example also reveals that (a) `VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_add` is clearly the wrong way around, and (b) we need a `TopologicalSpace` instance for `ZMod` as well as a `MeasurableSpace` one.)

I'm not sure I like this middle-ground since you lose the ability to rewrite. Personally, I heavily rely on the rewriting behavior and can't afford to lose it.

On the other hand, if you are happy for my discrete Fourier transform API (for general finite abelian groups) to coexist (at least temporarily) with the content of this PR, then I don't really care about the technicalities of this PR and am basically happy with it.

> I'm not sure I like this middle-ground since you lose the ability to rewrite. Personally, I heavily rely on the rewriting behavior and can't afford to lose it.
> 
> On the other hand, if you are happy for my discrete Fourier transform API (for general finite abelian groups) to coexist (at least temporarily) with the content of this PR, then I don't really care about the technicalities of this PR and am basically happy with it.

I'm completely happy for multiple approaches to discrete Fourier theory to coexist.

(PS. Just so I can better understand your comment, can you give an example of the kind of "rewriting behaviour" that you are saying would be lost?)

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#13579~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#13872~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#13878~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#13937~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Ready for review once more

Thanks for the (re-)review! Good point about `natCast` as well as `intCast`, that actually simplifies several other arguments since it meshes better with `ZMod.val` being `Nat`-valued. I added the corresponding lemma for `Circle` as well as `AddCircle`.

Thanks Yael for the comments – I have incorporated them. I promise there will be more API in follow-up PRs; but this PR is a bit of a pain to work on at present (because it involves edits to widely-separated files in the import hierarchy), so I'd rather get it in as it stands.

Okay then

maintainer merge

Odd.

maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9827099070/job/27129402229)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9827099070/job/27129401967)
Rest looks good, except for the fact that your new definition has no API (but apparently that's a conscious design decision on your part)

Following the Zulip discussion, what is your plan between the following two?
* Copy over the API
* Make the user unfold `dft` every time they need a `fourierIntegral` lemma?
Rest looks good, except for the fact that your new definition has no API (but apparently that's a conscious design decision on your part)
Should this use any `n : Nat` together with an assumption `[NeZero n]`? It would apply to `ZMod n` even if `n` a `PNat` coerced to `Nat`.

Aha, that's a really good idea! In the next phase of the project I was constantly getting tangled in things like (1 : ℕ+) not being the same as `(1 : ℕ)` and I was sure there had to be a better way. This is clearly the right approach, thanks!

```suggestion
noncomputable def toCircle {N : ℕ+} : AddChar (ZMod N) circle :=
  AddChar.toAddMonoidHomEquiv.symm toAddCircle 
```

This does not work. 

Firstly `AddChar.toAddMonoidHomEquiv` has some arguments; you probably meant
`(AddChar.toAddMonoidHomEquiv _ _).symm toAddCircle`. But that just exposes the more serious problem that `UnitAddCircle` is not defined as the additivization of `circle`.
First problem is solved in #13579. Second problem, okay sure
This is an unbearably long name to include in lemma names.
Happy to rename it as `ZMod.dft` if you prefer.
Yeah, that would be great
This should just be a global instance
Can all of these move to earlier files?
I have moved all the content which doesn't specifically refer to Fourier theory to other places in the hierarchy (creating two small new files for things which didn't seem to have a natural home).

[Fin.instMeasurableSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/MeasurableSpace/Basic.html#Fin.instMeasurableSpace) is in `MeasureTheory.MeasurableSpace.Basic`, so I guess the `MeasurableSpace (ZMod n)` instance could go there?
That file's already 2200 lines long; we should be moving stuff out of it, not adding more.
See [#13937](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13937)
Okay, what about now?
Give me a few hours, I do have a day job too 😄

```suggestion
  `ZMod.stdAddChar` (mapping `j mod N` to `exp (2 * π * I * j / N)`). The notation `𝓕`, scoped in
```

```suggestion
lemma toCircle_intCast (j : ℤ) :
```
You're missing `DiscreteMeasurableSpace (ZMod N)`

It's not needed, since the following works:
```lean
example (n : ℕ) : DiscreteMeasurableSpace (ZMod n) := inferInstance
```
It's putting a bit more trust in looping instances than I am comfortable with, but sure

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.AddChar
import Mathlib.Analysis.Complex.Circle
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Complex.Log
```
This is a no-op, right? Or is the order of `import` statements significant somehow?
We are semitrying to keep it alphabetical. And no it's not a no-op, although exceptions are hard to spot
In case it wasn't clear, I have already applied your suggestion; thank you for explaining the reasoning behind it. Are you content with this PR now?

Sorry, I'm reviewing every time I am commuting (the point of my github status being to let you know about this) and I have very little time on a computer with internet connection, so I can only do superficial reviews. Hopefully I will have time tonight to send this PR off, but no promise.

```suggestion
lemma toAddCircle_intCast (j : ℤ) :
```
and you're missing `toAddCircle_natCast`

You're missing `toAddCircle_inj`, and
```suggestion
@[simp] lemma toAddCircle_eq_zero {j : ZMod N} :
```

```suggestion
  refine Fintype.sum_congr rfl fun j ↦ ?_
```

I'm afraid your suggestion does not work. (It took me a while to spot since there's a lot of library to compile in between `Topology.Instances.AddCircle` and here.) 

I guess you meant either `Finset.sum_congr rfl fun j _ ↦ ?_` or `Fintype.sum_congr _ _ fun j ↦ ?_`. However, while playing with this I spotted that `congr 1 with j` also works, and IMHO that's nicer than any of these other possibilities, so I am going with that.

```suggestion
  simpa using toCircle_intCast j
```
is a more robust proof
The "more robust proof" does not quite work because it cannot infer `N` in the argument. I went for `simpa using toCircle_intCast (N := N) j`.

I would add a docstring warning that this lemma is "evil" in that it refers to `ZMod.val` which is an unmathematical function that could put you in a cul-de-sac (as a matter of fact, it happened to me several times already) and that the user shouild instead lift `j` to `Int` and use `toCircle_intCast`
Makes sense. I had noticed the "cul-de-sac" issue which is why I didn't tag this lemma as simp. I will add a warning to the docstring as you suggest.
PS. The docstring would be more useful if we had an induction principle for ZMod. Surprisingly this seems to be absent.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/Fourier): discrete Fourier transform on `ZMod N`

nodes.body:
Following the Zulip discussion, what is your plan between the following two?
* Copy over the API
* Make the user unfold `dft` every time they need a `fourierIntegral` lemma?

I'm thinking of a middle ground. If applying some general lemma from the Fourier transform API "just works", then I don't see there's a pressing need to create a copy. So e.g. compatibility with scalar-multiplication works out of the box, but addition needs some side conditions:
```lean
example {N : ℕ} [NeZero N] (Φ : ZMod N → ℂ) (c : ℂ) : 𝓕 (c • Φ) = c • 𝓕 Φ := 
  VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_smul_const .. -- no need for a special DFT lemma

example {N : ℕ} [NeZero N] (Φ₁ Φ₂ : ZMod N → ℂ) : 𝓕 (Φ₁ + Φ₂) = 𝓕 Φ₁ + 𝓕 Φ₂ := by
  rw [Eq.comm] -- doh!
  apply VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_add 
  · continuity
  · continuity
  · measurability
  · measurability
```
(This example also reveals that (a) `VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_add` is clearly the wrong way around, and (b) we need a `TopologicalSpace` instance for `ZMod` as well as a `MeasurableSpace` one.)

I'm not sure I like this middle-ground since you lose the ability to rewrite. Personally, I heavily rely on the rewriting behavior and can't afford to lose it.

On the other hand, if you are happy for my discrete Fourier transform API (for general finite abelian groups) to coexist (at least temporarily) with the content of this PR, then I don't really care about the technicalities of this PR and am basically happy with it.

> I'm not sure I like this middle-ground since you lose the ability to rewrite. Personally, I heavily rely on the rewriting behavior and can't afford to lose it.
> 
> On the other hand, if you are happy for my discrete Fourier transform API (for general finite abelian groups) to coexist (at least temporarily) with the content of this PR, then I don't really care about the technicalities of this PR and am basically happy with it.

I'm completely happy for multiple approaches to discrete Fourier theory to coexist.

(PS. Just so I can better understand your comment, can you give an example of the kind of "rewriting behaviour" that you are saying would be lost?)
